questions.text: In a patient presenting with rectal prolapse, which of the following procedures is not done via the perineal approach?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ripstein procedure The Ripstein operation uses permanent polypropylene mesh to fix the rectum to the presacral fascia, thereby restoring the normal posterior curve of the rectum and eliminating intussusception and prolapse. Ripstein operation is the abdominal approach for rectal prolapse

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A: Altemeier rectosigmoidectomy - involves removal of the prolapsed rectum and associated sigmoid colon, followed by which a coloanal anastomosis is created. Option B: Delorme’s mucosectomy - involves mucosal stripping and muscle plication of the rectal prolapse using interrupted sutures. It is performed externally under regional or general anesthesia. Option C: Thiersch’s encirclement- a steel wire, or Silastic or nylon tape, is placed around the anal canal. Largely obsolete now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation

questions.text: Match the following with their regards to thyroid swelling obstruction: Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A4 , B 1, C2, D 3 Trachea : Dyspnoea Esophagus : Dysphagia Recurrent laryngeal nerve : Hoarseness of voice Sympathetic chain : Horner’s syndrome

Highyeild:

Large thyroid swelling may compress the surrounding structures and present as pressure symptoms. Compression of the trachea can cause respiratory symptoms like dyspnea and stridor. Pressure on the esophagus causes dysphagia. Compression of the sympathetic chain leads to Horner’s syndrome. Unilateral paralysis of the recurrent laryngeal nerve produces hoarseness. Vocal cord paralysis from RLN compression is extremely rare and should raise concern for malignant change

questions.text: Drug used for trastuzumab-resistant her 2 positive breast cancer is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lapatinib Lapatinib, used in the form of lapatinib ditosylate, is an orally active drug for trastuzumab-resistant her 2 positive breast cancer

Highyeild:

Lapatinib is a potent reversible and selective inhibitor of the tyrosine kinase domains of epidermal growth factor receptor and human epidermal growth factor receptor (HER)-2 that exerts its action by competitive binding to the intracellular ATP-binding site of the receptor. Used for the treatment of advanced or metastatic HER-2+ breast cancer in combination with capecitabine and for hormone receptor–positive breast cancer in combination with an aromatase inhibitor. Lapatinib administered orally once daily is moderately to well tolerated, with rash and gastrointestinal adverse events as the main toxicities and can also cause dose dependent prolongation of QT interval. unitinib is used in refractory metastatic breast cancer

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A: Vismodegib : Hedgehog pathway inhibitor used to treat metastatic and locally advanced basal cell carcinoma Option C: Erlotinib: Protein antagonists which is the line treatment of non small cell lung carcinoma with EGFR deletion of exon 19 or L858R mutation Option D: Vemurafenib: BRAF inhibitor used in metastatic melanoma and thyroid cancers.

questions.text: A patient presented with dysuria and pain in the back. His lumbar spine X- ray shows the below finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperparathyroidism The given clinical scenario and X-ray showing diffuse calcification of both kidneys are suggestive of nephrocalcinosis which is seen in hyperparathyroidism

Highyeild:

Nephrocalcinosis refers to generalized calcium deposition in the kidney and does not include the focal calcium deposition associated with focal renal injury Presentation Most commonly presents as an asymptomatic, chronic disease incidentally discovered on radiographic imaging of the abdomen Renal colic. Polyuria and polydipsia can occur with chronic hypercalcemia, medullary nephrocalcinosis, and in Bartter syndrome. Acute renal failure in instances such as tumor lysis syndrome and acute phosphate nephropathy. Treatment is directed to treat the underlying cause of nephrocalcinosis. Strategies to reduce the urinary concentration of calcium, phosphate, or oxalate Increased fluid intake Potassium citrate to treat hypocitraturia and pH less than 7 in Distal renal tubular acidosis

Extraedge:

Clinical features of hyperparathyroidism The signs and symptoms of primary hyperparathyroidism are classically summarized by the mnemonic “stones, bones, abdominal groans and psychiatric moans”. Stones refers to kidney stones, nephrocalcinosis and diabetes insipidus (polyuria and polydipsia). These can ultimately lead to renal failure. Bones refers to bone-related complications. The classic bone disease in hyperparathyroidism is osteitis fibrosa cystica, which results in pain and pathological fractures. Other bone diseases associated with hyperparathyroidism are osteoporosis, osteomalacia, and arthritis. Abdominal groans refers to gastrointestinal symptoms of indigestion, nausea, vomiting and constipation. Hypercalcaemia can lead to peptic ulcers and acute pancreatitis. Mental moans refers to effects on the central nervous system. Symptoms include psychosis, anxiety, lethargy, memory loss, depression and coma. Acronym for features of Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: A middle aged patient presented with Back pain, fatigue & dysuria. X Ray abdomen was done and shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Parathyroid adenoma Image is suggestive of Bilateral renal stones, making a diagnosis of Parathyroid adenoma likely. The given symptoms can be explained via the renal stones in parathyroid adenoma

Highyeild:

Parathyroid adenoma is the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism. It typically occurs as a single benign tumor in one of the parathyroid glands. PTH adenoma leads to excessive production of parathyroid hormone, resulting in hypercalcemia. Patients with PTH adenoma may present with symptoms such as fatigue,bone pain,kidney stones and gastrointestinal disturbances Diagnosis is confirmed by measuring elevated serum calcium and PTH levels

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option B: Wilms tumor: It typically presents as a renal mass on imaging studies, but it would not be the appropriate diagnosis based on the X-Ray image provided Option C: Renal cell carcinoma: The given history is not suggestive of of RCC and kidney stones in RCC are not common Option D: Lipoma is a benign tumor composed of fatty tissue. It typically appears as a well defined, soft tissue mass on imaging

questions.text: Most common cause of adrenal incidentaloma is______
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Non-functioning adenoma Non-secretory adrenal adenoma is a benign growth of the adrenal gland that is not hypersecretory. This is the most common type and constitutes up to 80% of all incidentalomas in some studies.

Highyeild:

Adrenal masses are often discovered incidentally and are then termed adrenal incidentalomas (AIs) Signs and symptoms of adrenal incidentaloma Pheochromocytoma like symptoms include episodic attacks, palpitations, sweats, headaches, and abdominal pain, as well as labile hypertension. Primary hyperaldosteronism includes hypertension and unprovoked hypokalemia. Weight loss, Virilization, Feminization Cushing syndrome (reflecting cortisol-secreting adenomas) includes weight gain, weakness, depression, and bruising Workup in adrenal incidentaloma Biochemical tests used are Pheochromocytoma - Urine-free and plasma-free metanephrines Primary aldosteronism - Plasma aldosterone-to-renin ratio Adrenocortical carcinoma - Urine 17-ketosteroids Cushing or “silent” Cushing syndrome - Overnight 1-mg dexamethasone test The imaging modalities of choice in the evaluation of an adrenal mass are computed tomography (CT) scanning, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and positron-emission tomography (PET) scanning Adrenal incidentalomas fall into one of three categories: Functioning tumors : These tumors make too much of any of the hormones that the adrenal glands normally make and include aldosterone-producing adenomas, cortisol producing tumors, adrenaline producing tumors, or sex-hormone producing tumors Malignant tumors : Adrenocortical cancer and metastatic disease Benign, non-functional tumors : Adenomas, myelolipomas, ganglioneuromas, adrenal cysts, and hematomas.

questions.text: Which of the following are true statements about thymoma?

options.label: B
options.text: Thymoma is the most common neoplasia of the thymus

options.label: D
options.text: It is mostly symptomatic and compress esophagus

questions.correct_answer: B. Thymoma is the most common neoplasia of the thymus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thymoma is the most common neoplasia of the thymus

Highyeild:

Thymoma is the most common primary neoplasm of the thymus gland. Thymomas and thymic carcinomas originate from the epithelial cells of the thymus within the anterior mediastinum. Commonly occur between the fourth and sixth decades of life Thymoma is commonly associated with autoimmune disorders, such as myasthenia gravis and other paraneoplastic syndromes such as total red cell aplasia, polymyositis, systemic lupus erythematosus, Cushing syndrome, and SIADH Most common mutations in thymic tumors include: General transcription factor I p53 KIT Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 2A Presentation An incidental finding on imaging in an asymptomatic patient A patient symptomatic due to the local compressive effects of the mass within the thoracic cavity (e.g., dyspnea, cough) A patient symptomatic due to a paraneoplastic syndrome Diagnosis : Imaging with CT or MRI Chest. Diagnostic confirmation with biopsy Treatment : Complete surgical removal. Thymectomy leads to improvement of resolution of symptoms of myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: In a patient with an inguinal hernia, the surgeon reduces the entire hernial sac into the abdominal cavity without reducing the contents. What is this knowns as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reduction en masse The surgeon reducing the entire hernial sac into the abdominal cavity without reducing the contents is referred to as reduction en masse of the hernia

Highyeild:

Reduction en masse of inguinal hernia means reduction/migration of a herniated sac along with the incarcerated bowel into the properitoneal space. Properitoneal space lies between the anterior abdominal wall and parietal peritoneum. It can occur following multiple forced attempts to reduce the hernia, and present with small bowel obstruction in a patient with poorly reduced hernia Reduction en-masse of inguinal hernia is a clinical diagnosis which can be confirmed by CT. The hernial sac will contain bowel loop with wall enhancement and fluid suggestive of strangulation. Properitoneal hernia sac sign helps in identifying and confirming reduction en-masse of hernia Treatment : Immediate surgical repair

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A. Maydl hernia is characterized by the presence of two small bowel loops within a single hernia sac. It is W shaped Option B. An incarcerated hernia refers to a type of hernia in which the herniated tissue becomes trapped or stuck within the hernia sac or the opening through which it has pushed. This condition can be serious because the trapped tissue might not receive proper blood flow, leading to potential complications like tissue damage or even strangulation, which is a medical emergency. Option D. A strangulated hernia occurs when the hernia contents are ischemic due to a compromised blood supply. This phenomenon occurs most commonly when there is a small opening in the musculature and a significant quantity of contents within the hernia itself.

questions.text: Match the following positions of the appendix: Subcaecal Retrocaecal Inside the pelvis Paracaecal Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-b,2-d,3-a,4-c

Highyeild:

The appendix is a narrow, finger-shaped pouch that projects out from the colon. Appendicitis occurs when the appendix becomes inflamed and filled with pus. Appendicitis is an inflammation of the appendix, a finger-shaped pouch that projects from your colon on the lower right side of your abdomen. Continued growth of caecum rotates the appendix in different positions. The vermiform appendix is attached dorsomedially to the end of the cecum, where all three taeniae converge. It is 2 to 15 cm long and lies often intraperitoneally retrocecal (65%) or in the lesser pelvis (30%). The appendix is attached to the posterior abdominal wall by the mesoappendix The appendix positions are Retrocecal/retrocolic: the appendix courses upwardly behind the cecum, and may reach the initial portion of the ascending colon. Most common position Pelvic: the appendix is directed downward, over the psoas major, with its tip surpassing the upper edge of the lower pelvis. Post-ileal: the distal portion of the appendix is in a position posterior-superior to the terminal ileum and directed to the spleen Subcecal: the appendix is located under the cecum, resting on the right iliac fossa and separated from the iliac muscle by a local peritoneal lining Pre-ileal: the distal portion of the appendix is located in a position anterior-superior to the terminal ileum and directed to the spleen Paracecal position: the appendix is situated laterally to the cecum and ascending colon Other (ectopic) positions: the appendix does not fit in any of the positions above described. Alvarado scoring system

questions.text: Smoking increases the risk of which of the following diseases: (multiple correct) Duct ectasia Fibroadenoma Mondor disease CA breast Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,3,4 Smoking increases the risk factor for: 1. Duct ectasia 2. Breast carcinoma 3. Mondor disease

Highyeild:

Duct ectasia is defined as dilated major milk ducts. Smoking and diabetes are risk factors for duct ectasia Mondor’s disease is thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall. Risk factors include breast surgery, breast biopsy, breast cancer, and trauma. Smoking is also found to have an association with Mondor’s disease Smoking is a modifiable risk factor in case of CA Breast Smoking is not a risk factor for fibroadenomas. Protective factor’s Early age at first pregnency Multiparity Breast feeding Exercise Tamoxifen Oophorectomy

Solution:

Ranula

Highyeild:

A ranula is a fluid collection or cyst that forms in the mouth under the tongue. It is filled with saliva (spit) that has leaked out of a damaged salivary gland. A mucous extravasation cyst that arises from the sublingual gland that resembles a frog belly Etiology : Local trauma and duct rupture, followed by mucin spillage into the surrounding soft tissues (mucous extravasation phenomenon) Histopathology Mucin accumulation surrounded by granulation and fibrous tissue (mucous extravasation phenomenon) A cyst cavity, filled with mucin and lining by the ductal epithelium (mucous retention cyst) Chronic inflammation of the cyst wall is present. Infiltration by numerous neutrophils, histiocytes, and plasma cells are common Clinical Features Exclusively present on the floor of mouth Usually unilateral, lateral to midline Smooth, dome shape, fluctuating and painless swelling The color is usually bluish, but deep lesions may have a normal color. The size varies from a few to several centimeters in diameter. Very large lesions which may occupy the floor of mouth can also occur Treatment Surgical removal or marsupialization MC structure injured during ranula surgery: Submandibular duct

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Options A: Hemangioma is the most common vascular tumor and is characterized by increased abnormal proliferation of endothelium. Hemangiomas develop in infancy and are usually not visible at birth. They appear red or maroon if superficial, and bluish if deep. Option B: Cystic hygroma is usually seen in neonates and early childhood. They are cystic swellings filled with lymph fluid and are characteristically brilliantly translucent. They occur in the neck and can involve the parotid, submandibular, tongue, etc. The swelling is soft and partially compressible. Definitive treatment is the excision of the swelling. Option C: The branchial cyst develops from the vestigial remnants of the second branchial cleft. Swelling in the neck beneath the anterior border of the upper third of the sternomastoid muscle. It is smooth, soft, fluctuant, and often transilluminate.

questions.text: Identify the surgical instrument shown in the image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mixter’s Forceps The given instrument is a Mixter’s right angle forceps that can be used to pass ligatures and dissect pedicles

Random:

Explanation for other options: -

questions.text: A 73-year-old patient presents with painless rectal bleeding. Which of the below-mentioned investigations are done for this patient? CECT CA 19-9 levels CEA levels Colonoscopy Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A,C,D

Highyeild:

Rectal bleeding occours due to pathology of the lower gastrointestinal tract below the ligament of treitz. The differential that can be considered in a case of rectal bleeding are: Colon cancer Inflammatory bowel disease Diverticular disease Hemorrhoids Angiodysplasia Colonoscopy with biopsy has a key role in the diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease and colorectal cancer is suspected especially in old patients. CECT is a principal investigation modality used in the diagnosis of Diverticular diseases and assessing the extent of disease in carcinoma colon CEA is a non-specific marker elevated in the CA colon and hence can be used as a part of routine examination. CA 19-9 levels is a blood test that measures the level of a protein that is associated with pancreatic cancer. High levels of CA 19-9 can indicate pancreatic cancer or other types of cancer or noncancerous disorders. CA 19-9 levels can also reflect the response to treatment or the recurrence of the tumor

questions.text: Which of the following are done in Breast Conservation Surgery? Wide local excision Intra op frozen section needed Axillary Node dissection post operative radiotherapy optional Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2,3 Wide local excision, Intraoperative operative frozen section and Axillary Node dissection are part of breast conservation surgery

Highyeild:

Breast-conserving therapy refers to breast-conserving surgery (BCS; ie, lumpectomy) typically followed by radiation therapy (RT) to eradicate any microscopic residual disease. It is an alternative to mastectomy for patients with early breast cancer. Prior to the advent of BCT, all breast cancers were treated with mastectomy. An operation that aims to remove breast cancer while avoiding a mastectomy. Different forms of this operation include: lumpectomy (tylectomy), wide local excision, segmental resection, and quadrantectomy. Breast-conserving surgery has been increasingly accepted as an alternative to mastectomy in specific patients, as it provides tumor removal while maintaining an acceptable cosmetic outcome.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A. Wide local excision is done under breast conservative surgery Option B. Intra operative frozen section needed is required during this procedure Option C. Axillary Node dissection is the part of breast conservative surgery

questions.text: A patient presents with dull aching pain in both legs. He gives a history of prolonged standing and tortuous veins in the legs. Which of the saphenofemoral incompetence? Brodie Trendelenburg test Fegans test Morrissey’s test Modified perthes test Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A,C,D The following tests done for SFJ incompetence will be positive A. Brodie Trendelenburg test B. Morrissey’s test C. Modified perthes test D. Fegan’s test

Highyeild:

Tests for Varicose Veins Morrissey’s test : Cough impulse test Perthe’s test : Affected lower extremity is wrapped with elastic bandage and patient is instructed to move around and exercise. Increase in size of the varices indicates incompetence of deep venous system. Severe crampy pain is suggestive of deep venous obstruction Modified Perthes test: Tourniquet is applied around the upper part of the thigh and patient is asked to walk quickly with tourniquet in the place Severe crampy pain is suggestive of deep venous obstruction Schwartz test In long standing varicose veins if the lower part of varicosity is tapped, an impulse is felt at the saphenous opening Fegans test Palpation to find the fascial defects to locate incompetent perforators

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A. Brodie Trendelenburg test is a test which can be carried out as part of a physical examination to determine the competency of the valves in the superficial and deep veins of the legs in patients with varicose veins. Option B. Fegans test Also known as Inferior Drawer test. Purpose: To check the inferior shoulder stability. It assesses humeral head inferior subluxation. Option D. Modified perthes The Perthes test is a clinical test for assessing the patency of the deep femoral vein prior to varicose vein surgery. It is named after German surgeon Georg Perthes. The limb is elevated and an elastic bandage is applied firmly from the toes to the upper 1/3 of the thigh to obliterate the superficial veins only. With the bandage applied the patient is asked to walk for 5 minutes. If deep system is competent, the blood will go through and back to the heart. If the deep system is incompetent, the patient will feel pain in the leg.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presenting with 36 weeks of gestation, underwent a C-Section for placenta accreta spectrum. During the procedure, there was profuse bleeding and she was transfused blood according to the massive blood transfusion protocol. Which of the following is not seen after a massive blood transfusion?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypokalemia It is not a complication of massive transfusion rather hyperkalemia is critical condition pop up as complication of massive transfusion

Highyeild:

Massive transfusion is traditionally defined as transfusion of 10 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) within a 24 hour period. The goal of massive transfusion is to limit complications and to limit critical hypoperfusion while surgical hemostasis can be achieved. Clinical Significance associated with blood transfusion Hemolytic Transfusion Reaction (HTR) Allergic Transfusion Reactions (ATRs) Transfusion-related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI) Transfusion-associated Circulatory Overload (TACO) Transfusion-associated graft versus Host Disease (TAGvHD) Alloimmunization. Other Non-infectious Complications.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option B. Hypocalcaemia:It presents as circumoral paresthesia Option C. Hypomagnesemia: Hypomagnesemia associated with massive blood transfusions is not uncommon and presumed to be due to citrate toxicity, hemodilution Option D. Hypothermia:Rapid transfusion of blood components at 4 degree celsius

questions.text: Which of the following is not an advantage of USG over mammography?

options.label: A
options.text: USG can be used to detect mammography Undetectable tumors which are palpable

options.label: B
options.text: Can be used to differentiate solid VS cystic lesion

options.label: C
options.text: Can be used for guided biopsy

options.label: D
options.text: In young females with dense breast

questions.correct_answer: A. USG can be used to detect mammography Undetectable tumors which are palpable
questions.explanation:
Solution:

USG can be used to detect mammography Undetectable tumors which are palpable USG cannot be used for screening mammographically undetectable clinically nonpalpable breast mass

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option B. Can be used to differentiate solid VS cystic lesion :. Ultrasound imaging can help distinguish between solid and cystic lesions. This is an advantage of USG. Option C. Can be used for guided biopsy :USG can be used for guided biopsy. This statement is an advantage of USG. A USG guided biopsy is a procedure in which ultrasound imaging used to precisely guide the needle during a biopsy,helping to ensure accurate sampling of suspicious areas. Option D. In young females with dense breast: In young females with dense breasts. This statement is an advantage of USG. Young females with dense breast tissue often face challenges with mammography due to overlapping density that can obscure small abnormalities.
